column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Choose Recipes if You Have Sensory Issues
#Text=If you have sensory issues and experience sensitivity to sounds , smells , flavors , or textures , mealtimes may be a challenge .
#Text=If you ’re stuck in a rut trying to find meals , know that there are lots of ways to eat nutritious foods that you also can enjoy .
#Text=Try new foods by keeping familiar elements in your recipes .
#Text=Make small tweaks instead of major changes .
#Text=Play with different textures until you find some that you enjoy .
#Text=If you struggle greatly , consider seeing a professional for help .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Choosing Meals that Appeal to You
#Text=Avoid recipes that rely on ingredients with a strong aroma .
#Text=This might include cooked onions or garlic , strong spices , or other aromas you find displeasing .
#Text=If a recipe calls for a strongly scented food , omit it or find a replacement that is more pleasing to you .
#Text=For example , substitute other vegetables ( such as broccoli or green pepper ) in place of onions .
#Text=Some other foods to avoid cooking because of their aroma might include ginger , cinnamon , or meat .
#Text=Choose preparation methods that are quiet .
#Text=If noise bothers you , avoid recipes that require loud sounds , such as the blender or mixer .
#Text=This might mean mixing ingredients by hand or cutting foods into small pieces on your own .

#Text=For example , if you want to make a smoothie but do n’t want to listen to the blender , make a simplified smoothie by adding a powdered protein mix to a liquid ( such as almond milk ) and shaking it in a covered cup .
#Text=Stick to your preferred food textures .
#Text=You may prefer soft foods or crunchy foods .
#Text=Whatever your preference , you can choose recipes that use those types of foods .
#Text=For example , if you enjoy eating soft textures , choose recipes which cook the vegetables instead of eating them raw , or choose mashed potatoes over potato wedges .
#Text=If you prefer crunchy textures , add nuts to your meals as a garnish .
#Text=Build off of preferred textures .
#Text=Narrow your choices by searching recipes which include a food with a pleasant texture as a base .
#Text=It might be too much to venture into trying full new recipes , so stick to the textures you prefer and add onto them .
#Text=For example , if you enjoy rice , look for rice dishes or meals that include rice as a major ingredient .
#Text=This might mean making a stir fry , rice porridge , or a risotto .
#Text=Prepare foods with an undesirable texture in a new way .
#Text=If you avoid foods due to their texture , think about using a new method to prepare or eat them .
#Text=For example , you may dislike soggy cereal , so eat it dry or with yogurt instead of milk .
#Text=Find creative ways to prepare foods so that you do n’t run into issues with texture .
#Text=If you dislike the texture of mushrooms , cut them into small pieces and put them into a dish with other foods you enjoy .
#Text=If you do n’t enjoy mushrooms as the main course , use them in a smaller role .
#Text=Making Minor Adjustments to Meals
#Text=Make small changes to foods .
#Text=You do n’t have to get entirely out of your comfort zone to experience new things .
#Text=Make a recipe you ’ve made before but tweak 1 or 2 things about it .
#Text=For example , if you like to eat noodles , try ramen or udon noodles 1 night .
#Text=If you enjoy rice , try brown rice 1 night .
#Text=Making small changes to things you tend to like can help you discover new flavors and new recipes .
#Text=Do n’t make more than 1 or 2 changes per recipe .
#Text=If you find a recipe in a cookbook , tailor it to your tastes with minimal changes to what you normally eat .
#Text=Sneak healthy foods into your favorite recipes .
#Text=If you hate the texture of certain vegetables and struggle to eat enough , try cutting or blending them and putting them in foods you enjoy .
#Text=Find ways to ‘ hide ’ healthy foods that have a difficult texture for you so that you can still eat the foods you enjoy , just with some added nutrition .
#Text=For example , add vegetables to pasta sauce or micro-chopped carrots into a spread or dip .
#Text=Do n’t just stop at meals , try adding healthy foods to desserts as well !
#Text=Add condiments to iffy foods .
#Text=Find which condiments you enjoy the most and add them to new or questionable foods .
#Text=Knowing that you enjoy one food item can help you be open to enjoying another item .
#Text=If you ’re trying a new recipe as a guest at someone ’s house , consider bringing your own condiments such as mustard , mayonnaise , or ketchup if you are n’t sure they will be available .
#Text=Make mealtime predictable .
#Text=One way to reduce stress around foods is to make mealtimes predictable and routine .
#Text=Serve meals at the same time each day .
#Text=Eat off of the same dinnerware each time .
#Text=While these routines are simple , they can help ease stress by creating predictability and structure .
#Text=Getting Additional Help
#Text=Keep a record of which foods you enjoy .
#Text=Have some ‘ go-to ’ foods that you know you enjoy and can eat regularly .
#Text=People with sensory processing problems often enjoy bland foods such as pasta , rice , or potatoes .
#Text=Try using these foods as a base for a recipe and try something new to go with it .
#Text=That way , you ’ll eat something you know you enjoy but also have the opportunity to try something new .
#Text=Seek guidance from a dietitian .
#Text=A registered dietitian can help you determine what foods to eat more or less of based on your needs .
#Text=They can answer any questions you may have about diet , supplements , and nutrition .
#Text=If you struggle to feel nourished after your meals , consult with a specialist to get a better idea of how to better balance your meals .
#Text=Ask your doctor to recommend a registered dietitian or look online at http://www.eatright.org/find-an-expert .
#Text=Make an appointment with an occupational therapist .
#Text=If your sensory issues keep you from eating a balanced and nutritious diet , consider seeing an occupational therapist .
#Text=Many people who struggle with foods tend to have other sensory issues that affect them outside of mealtime .
#Text=An occupational therapist can help you accept more tastes and textures with your food selections and other sensitivities that may affect your day-to-day living .
#Text=Schedule an appointment with an occupational therapist by calling your insurance provider or a local health clinic near you .
#Text=You can also speak with your physician for a referral or for a recommendation .
